results.title: Northern Territory Contact. No. 12
results.creator_credit: Ian Walker, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Solar village. In the little township of Nguiu, on Bathurst Island a solar power plant run by First Nations people, has been built, which supplies electricity to the settlement of 800 people.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Walker, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia

results.title: Weipa people
results.creator_credit: Edwin Scragg, Jane Scragg, Comalco and Scope Films
results.brief_description: A film about the largest bauxite mining operation in the world. Also looks at the social conditions of the people who have moved to this remote North Queensland town and the impact of the new town on local First Nations peoples. Commentary by Richard Oxenburgh.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edwin Scragg, Jane Scragg, Comalco and Scope Films

results.title: People out of time
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World about us”.
A study of the Bindubi tribe, Australian First Nations people who have mastered their arid, inhospitable environment in the Great Sandy Desert by using every resource to the maximum point of refinement. Filmed on Professor Donald Thompson’s 1963 expedition. Narrated by Leo McKern, filmed by David Corke and Len McLarty, written and presented by Eric Davidson.

results.title: Aborigines of the Northern Territory: scouting outpost
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Frank Bagnall, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Cinesound Movietone
results.brief_description: Scouting has become an important activity among young children of Maningrida on the Arafura Sea in Northern Australia. In 1964 a school teacher introduced scouting, and its popularity led to the growth of the movement to include Cubs, Rovers and Guides. Young people from eleven First Nations peoples in the area are involved.

results.title: The Conciliation by Benjamin Duterrau, 1840
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton, Film Australia and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye II”.
This film looks at the works of Benjamin Duterrau, and in particular his painting “The Conciliation”. This was of importance as, based on the meeting of George Augustus Robinson in 1830 with a group of Tasmanian First Nations people, it was the first painting of a historical scene created in Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Muir, Malcolm Otton, Film Australia and Tasmanian Film Corporation

results.title: Murawina: self help
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Jan Sharp, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our multicultural society”.
Murawina is a First Nations pre-school in Chippendale, an inner suburb of Sydney. The mothers who run Murawina want a separate pre-school for their children, because they want to develop in their children a black pride that may not be encouraged by the white schools the children will next go to. The film raises questions about prejudice, the influence of past experiences on present day attitudes and the relationship between urban and tribal First Nations peoples.

results.title: We have to start somewhere
results.creator_credit: Eric Fullilove, Peter Richman and Banks Noel Paton
results.brief_description: This film is about development. A discussion group covers, among other things, migrants, First Nations peoples and the relationships between rich and poor nations and the consequences of preaching Christianity without due reverence for other cultures. The film stresses the need for commitment to action

results.title: The Land my mother = Walya ngamardiki
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, India Bharti, Tom Manefield and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Inspired by Silas Roberts, a tribal elder of the Allawa clan who wrote to the 1976 Australian Government inquiry on uranium mining, this film gives an insight into the local First Nations peoples’ attitudes towards uranium mining. They tell of the myths and legends associated with the land and their sacred places, and why they object to the mining being carried out. Commentary by Bob Maza.

results.title: Walking in the sunlight, walking in the shadow
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Joe Scully and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Education and social integration of Northern Territory First Nations peoples. Considers the position of First Nations peoples in Australia, particularly in the Northern areas. Australians in other parts of the country is exposed to the poor social conditions experienced in the newspaper and on television, but how is the situation viewed in the Northern Territory? Includes interviews with those involved and scenes of contemporary First Nations peoples’ lives.

results.title: A Voice to be heard
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Anthony Buckley and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In 1973 the National Aboriginal Consultative Committee (N.A.C.C.) was elected for the purpose of giving First Nations people a direct voice in the government. This was the first Australia-wide, elected and representative body of First Nations people in Australia’s history. This film, narrated by the poet Kath Walker, tells the story of the election up to the declaration of the poll and the first meeting of the N.A.C.C. Also takes a searching look at the social conditions of First Nations people as some of the candidates for election speak about their problems.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Greg Reading, Anthony Buckley and Film Australia
